item.title: Tree needs felling or pollarding, and footway repaired, 7th August
item.description:
This tree (outside 218) has become overgrown, excessively tall in relation to the houses, with a canopy spanning the width of our house and the adjoining semi, with overhanging branches on both properties, constantly shedding twigs, leaves and needles over our and the neighbouring property. The root ball is well above ground level and significantly lifting and breaking up the footpath, with numerous breaks, cracks and eruptions over the 15 metre tarmacked section of the footpath. We are concerned that further root growth will invade our property and cause damage. Additionally, there is excessive foliage, with large thorns, growing over 6 foot tall, around the base of the tree, overhanging the footpath, and presenting a safety risk to footpath users. Critically the foliage makes it difficult/impossible to see approaching traffic without stepping into the road when using the adjacent pedestrian refuge crossing, and blocks the view of oncoming traffic when trying to exit our driveway by car. Please can this tree be cut down (as recently done, 21 July, with one tree in adjacent Chaucer Road), the foliage removed, and the footpath restored to a safe and level surface. If the tree is not felled, please can it be heavily pollarded (as done with two trees, 21 July, in Chaucer Road), foliage growth around the base removed and remedial work put in place for a long term fix to making the footbath safe and level, and addressing foliage and root growth. We would note that previous work to tarmac over the footpath without providing a long term fix to root growth, has proved ineffective and needs a more permanent solution, ie, the tree to be cut down.

Nearest road to the pin placed on the map (automatically generated by OpenStreetMap): 216, Hurst Road, Albany Park, Sidcup, London
Report on FixMyStreet

item.title: There are 6 x large bins blocking pavement access, 7th August
item.description:
There are 6 x large bins (paper and general waste) blocking the access along the pavement. A large pram would struggle to pass by them. They have been there for over 4 months and rubbish is building up around them.

Nearest road to the pin placed on the map (automatically generated by OpenStreetMap): John Wilson Street, London
Report on FixMyStreet

item.title: Dumped cupboard and dangerous concrete bricks, 7th August
item.description:
